perturbation.original_text: Rogers shall pay to Licensor a fee (the "License Fee"), which shall be equal to fifty (50)% of Retail Revenues.   For the purposes of this Agreement, "Retail Revenues" means the retail revenues actually received by Rogers for each authorized exhibition of a Licensed Program on the ROD Service, less GST and applicable sales tax. For greater certainty, Retail Revenues shall not include any fees payable to Rogers for: (i) the purchase, rental or installation of a digital terminal; (ii) any basic or premium television services; or (iii) digital cable access.
perturbation.changed_text: Rogers shall pay to Licensor a fee (the "License Fee"), which shall be equal to fifty (50)% of Gross Receipts. For the purposes of this Agreement, "Retail Revenues" means the total revenues actually received by Rogers for each authorized exhibition of a Licensed Program on the ROD Service, less GST and applicable sales tax. For greater certainty, Gross Receipts shall not include any fees payable to Rogers for: (i) the purchase, rental or installation of a digital terminal; (ii) any basic or premium television services; or (iii) digital cable access.
perturbation.explanation: The terms "License Fee", "Retail Revenues" and "Gross Receipts" are being used interchangably and creates confusion since 'Retail Revenues' is defined clearly, but 'Gross Receipts' is not, thus creating uncertainty on how Rogers is required to pay Licensor.

perturbation.original_text: During the Term, Rogers shall have the non-exclusive right to distribute and exhibit each Licensed Program on a VOD basis for a period of ninety (90) consecutive days, or such longer period as may be agreed to by Rogers and Licensor (the "License Period").     5. VIEWING PERIOD.   The viewing period for each Licensed Program shall be at least twenty-four (24) consecutive hours, or such longer period as may be agreed to by Rogers and Licensor from time to time (the "Viewing Period").
perturbation.changed_text: During the Term, Rogers shall have the non-exclusive right to distribute and exhibit each Licensed Program on a VOD basis for a period of ninety (90) consecutive days, or such longer period as may be agreed to by Rogers and Licensor (the "Exhibition Window").     5. VIEWING PERIOD.   The viewing period for each Licensed Program shall be at least twenty-four (24) consecutive hours, or such longer period as may be agreed to by Rogers and Licensor from time to time (the "Viewing Period").
perturbation.explanation: In section 4, the term 'License Period' is replaced by 'Exhibition Window.' It’s unclear whether "Exhibition Window” and “License Period” are interchangeable. This could lead to disputes regarding rights to exhibit content after ninety days.

perturbation.original_text: Licensor agrees to pay to Rogers an amount which shall be equal to ten (10)% of License Fees, calculated on a rolling basis during the Term and payable monthly.     13. PRODUCTION FUND.   For so long as Rogers is required by Applicable Law to contribute a percentage of its gross annual revenues from the ROD Service to an independently-administered Canadian program production fund, Licensor shall reimburse Rogers for 50% of the amount required to be remitted to such production fund by Rogers in respect of the exhibition of Licensed Programs (the "Production Fund Commitment").
perturbation.changed_text: Licensor agrees to pay to Rogers an amount which shall be equal to ten (10)% of License Fees, calculated on a rolling basis during the Term and payable monthly.     13. PRODUCTION FUND.   For so long as Rogers is required by Applicable Law to contribute a percentage of its total annual income from the ROD Service to an independently-administered Canadian program production fund, Licensor shall reimburse Rogers for 50% of the amount required to be remitted to such production fund by Rogers in respect of the exhibition of Licensed Programs (the "Production Fund Commitment").
perturbation.explanation: Here, the term "gross annual revenues" is replaced by "total annual income". The meaning and scope of 'revenues' and 'income' are different as 'income' includes any money coming into the company, regardless whether it's profit. As the terms are being used interchangably it's difficult to determine what is considered when Rogers is determining their production fund.
